content.user_title: Slack GIF Creator - Animated GIF Generator for Slack
content.value_statement: Create professional, optimized animated GIFs for Slack with automatic size optimization, validation tools, and smooth animation utilities.
actual_capabilities: Generate animated GIFs from programmatic frames using PIL
Optimize GIFs for Slack's size and dimension requirements (128x128 emoji, 480x480 message)
Validate GIFs against Slack constraints (dimensions, file size, frame count)
Apply easing functions for smooth animations (bounce, elastic, ease-in/out)
Reduce file size through color quantization, frame deduplication, and compression
Draw graphics using PIL primitives (circles, polygons, stars, text, gradients)
Create common animation effects (pulse, shake, spin, fade, bounce, slide, explode)
Work with user-uploaded images for animation
limitations: Does not include pre-built emoji graphics or animation templates
Requires manual frame generation using PIL drawing primitives
No automatic upload to Slack (outputs file only)

best_practices: Use 10-15 FPS for emoji GIFs to keep file size small
Keep emoji GIF duration under 3 seconds for best performance
Apply remove_duplicates=True to eliminate nearly identical frames
Use optimize_for_emoji=True for automatic 128x128 resizing and aggressive optimization
Set num_colors between 48-64 for emoji (128 for message GIFs)
Use thicker lines (width=2+) for shapes to avoid choppy appearance
Combine easing functions for natural motion (ease_out for stops, bounce_out for impacts)
Validate GIFs with is_slack_ready() before uploading to Slack
Layer multiple shapes and add gradients for polished, professional look
anti_patterns: Don't use width=1 for lines/outlines - looks amateurish and choppy
Avoid relying on emoji fonts - they render inconsistently across platforms
Don't create 30 FPS GIFs for emoji - file size will be too large
Don't skip validation - Slack will reject oversized or incorrectly dimensioned GIFs
Avoid plain, single-shape graphics - add depth with gradients, layers, highlights
Don't use linear easing for everything - natural motion requires easing functions
Don't assume pre-built graphics exist in the skill - draw from scratch with PIL

faq.question: What size should my Slack emoji GIF be?
faq.answer: 128x128 pixels is optimal for Slack emoji. The skill can auto-resize with optimize_for_emoji=True.

faq.question: How do I reduce file size if my GIF is too large?
faq.answer: Use fewer frames (lower FPS), reduce colors (num_colors=48), enable remove_duplicates=True, or use optimize_for_emoji=True for automatic optimization.

faq.question: Can I animate an image I upload?
faq.answer: Yes, use PIL's Image.open() to load your image, then create frames by transforming it (rotate, scale, position changes).

faq.question: What animation effects are available?
faq.answer: The skill provides knowledge for: bounce, pulse/heartbeat, shake, spin, fade, slide, zoom, and particle explosions. Implement using PIL drawing and easing functions.

faq.question: How do I make smooth animations instead of jerky motion?
faq.answer: Use easing functions from core.easing like ease_out, bounce_out, or elastic_out instead of linear interpolation.

faq.question: Can this upload GIFs directly to Slack?
faq.answer: No, it creates the GIF file locally. You'll need to manually upload it to Slack or use Slack's API separately.

faq.question: How do I validate if my GIF meets Slack requirements?
faq.answer: Use validate_gif() or is_slack_ready() from core.validators to check dimensions, file size, and frame count.

permissions: File system write access (to save GIF files)
File system read access (to load user images if provided)
